content.description: This problem traverses the obvious rail on the lower portion of the cut boulder. I went left to right, although you could easily go right to left. Start on a good good low hold and bump up to the rail, then traverse the rail to the other side. Nothing special, but's a good warm up or a good problem if you’re looking for something low to the ground. I have no idea if anyone else has climbed this route. I assume people have, so I didn’t want to name it or claim the FA
content.location: Instead of turning right towards the cliffs, turn left and take a right turn down a path by a telephone pole. Walk around a wetland to the right, then pass the swamp boulder and thins climb is on the big boulder right behind It

content.description:
This problem starts low and goes up and to the right to the ledge to top out without getting uncomfortably high.

 The problem shares a start with gravity tax. You then climb up to the large rail. You then use some small holds to get your feet onto the rail and your body up on the slab. You then traverse right on the rail to a large pocket. From there you can reach your right hand to the arete and you may be able to reach a good crimp with your left(it's a far reach). Now you can get your right foot up on to a small vertical rail. You can then layback and pull your left foot into the pocket. From there you move your right hand up to a good victory jug and rock onto the ledge. Be careful getting down.
content.protection: a couple pads, or a good spotter.

content.description: Start low on two incut holds, working your feet up the ramp to a large jug. Move through a set of smaller holds to a set of smaller jugs, from here you might be able to down climb, but otherwise will have to commit to the crux.    Reach up and grab a very small in cut hold with your right hand, and work hard to find the other even smaller one with your left hand. From there adjust your feet and throw to the good crimp high and left at the terminus of a small crack. Catch this hold and throw to the lip of the boulder. It is a huge jug. Do not underestimate the mantle. Top it out and congratulate yourself on the evasion - falling from any of the crux moves would most certainly lead to you paying The Gravity Tax.
content.protection: Pads and spotters, the landing is not the greatest. It may be much more reasonable to set a top rope from a tree on the top of the boulder, or use the manky bolted anchor if you are bold enough to trust it.
content.location: This line follows a series of in cut holds up the middle of the face on the Cut boulder.

content.description: There are several decent sized boulders here that are deserving of a scrub and ascents - as well as one large face with a set of bolted anchors on the top (they're questionable and it is probably better to use pads). In the future I intend to update this information, and add photos and routes. Currently it appears as though no one has touched this rock in a time, although the bolted anchors indicate that there have been past ascents.
